results.title: Zoo babies
results.brief_description: Join Channel TEN’s Lynday Davies as she follows the lives of baby animals at Sydney’s Taronga and Western Plains Zoos. The zoo witnesses the birth of many babies throughout the year, with thousands of new additions to the zoo ‘family’. You’ll see the birth of a baby gorilla and giraffe, as well as an assortment of all creatures great and small who are cared for by zoo staff.

results.title: Youth of Japan
results.brief_description: Like young people everywhere, the youth of modern Japan display vision, hope and enthusiasm for life and strength of purpose. This is illustrated by impressions of the lives of a typical young factory worker, shop assistant and student.

results.title: Your silent partner
results.creator_credit: O.J. Wrightson and Tasmania. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Outlines methods of fodder conservation on the dairy farm. The cow may be regarded as a milk factory and if food is in short supply or of the wrong type, milk production will be reduced. The composition of milk is used to illustrate the need for a balanced diet and how such a diet can be obtained from different types of fodder. The latter sections of the film illustrate methods of making grass silage and meadow hay to provide a reserve of fodder for use throughout the year.

results.title: Your richest gift
results.brief_description: A good industrial safety record is the result of co-operation between management and employees. Safety equipment and safe working habits are necessary to prevent accidents. To protect the eyes safety glasses or goggles should be worn at all times. Shows the safety procedures operating at the Owens-Illinois factory.

results.title: Your obedient servant
results.brief_description: To the layman the world of the computer is surrounded by mystery. This film contends that it should be as acceptable in modern life as are the telephone and television. Man is master and a computer cannot work correctly unless each step is logically planned.

results.title: Your house and mine
results.creator_credit: Peter McIntyre and University of Melbourne. Dept. of Architecture
results.brief_description: This film documents styles of housing, with each sequence featuring a different aspect of Melbourne. There is some rare footage of the demolition of great Victorian mansions made during the boom era of the 1880s. Perspectives on housing needs are drawn from the voice-over comments (which are caricatures of Australian types), and are worked into pictures of Melbourne slums. Comical skits of haphazard “do-it-yourself” house builders are also shown. Eric Kerr shot and edited this film. One sequence has innovative, quick-cut editing with cue tones to show several houses of various design and style. Written by Robin Boyd and directed by Peter McIntyre. This title is also available for borrowing on VHS.

results.title: Your children and you
results.creator_credit: Brian Smith and British Ministry of Health
results.brief_description: Child care in the first years of life. Many hints on the correct care of infants and young children are given, from the weaning of the infant to the prevention of unnecessary fears, boredom, bad temper and maladjustment.

results.title: Young voices from the Arab world: the lives and times of five teenagers [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Leslie Nucho and Amideast, Washington, DC
results.brief_description: Five teenagers from various parts of the Arab world share their lives, experiences and hope for the future, providing an insight into everyday aspects of Arab culture and society. Their narratives and different locales reveal a place of contrasts, but also one of similarities in the shared cultural heritage, attitude towards family and religion, continuity and change. Fourteen-year-old Muhammad from Jordan explains how Islam guides his life, in particular the period of Ramadan and the haj. Fourteen-year-old Tamara from Beirut talks about the reconstruction of her city and her aspiration to be an archaeologist. Twelve-year-old Hazem lives in Egypt with his geologist parents and talks of the enjoyment he derives from movies and spending time with friends. Twelve-year-old Sa’ud lives with his extended family in Kuwait and has been told of many of the traditional ways, in danger of disappearing, by his grandmother. Twelve-year-old Khadija from Morocco talks about the differences between her generation and that of her mother. General information is also provided on the demographics, geography, religion, language, trade, industry, family and identity of the Arab world. A detailed teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
